General course objectives:
General course objectives
The objective is to give the students an understanding of the basic principles behind fusion energy and experimental plasma physics. The course will provide insight into plasma experiments and diagnostics required for the development of fusion energy. Acquired knowledge from this course provides a foundation for advanced studies of plasma physics at international plasma facilities and the local NORTH tokamak.
Learning objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
Describe basic properties of laboratory plasma used for fusion and ionospheric research
Identify breakdown methods for laboratory plasma
Apply MHD (magneto hydro dynamics) equations to obtain equilibrium states for magnetically confined plasma
Describe magnetic plasma confinement in toroidal devices: Tokamaks and Stellarators
List passive diagnostics for low and high temperature plasma
Identify active diagnostics for core measurements in fusion plasma
Apply cold plasma theory to describe wave propagation in laboratory plasma
Discuss fundamental heating methods for magnetically confined plasma
Design basic plasma diagnostics for current, density, and temperature measurements
Describe the main sources and sinks of power in fusion plasmas
Conduct and analyse experiments on the NORTH tokamak at DTU
Content: Description of the fundamental processes of fusion energy and how they will be exploited. Conditions for ignition of fusion energy, i.e., the condition for producing more energy by the fusion processes than the input energy. Confinement of hot fusion-grade plasma. Magnetic confinement in toroidal devices: tokamaks and stellarators. Plasma equilibrium states in tokamaks. Basic instabilities in magnetically confined plasma. Wave propagation in fusion plasmas. Basic plasma heating schemes. Diagnostics of fusion plasma.
